narrative_thread: Player attempted a vertical leap in the hallway. The world remains unimpressed.

room_start.name: Your Bedroom
room_start.description: The bedroom is a shrine to procrastination and half-finished projects. The queen-sized bed, unmade since... well, you can’t remember, dominates the space. A nightstand clutters the left side, its surface a graveyard of empty water glasses, a dog-eared paperback, and a lamp that’s seen better days. Across the room, a dresser stands guard over a pile of laundry—clean, but definitely not folded. The closet door hangs slightly ajar, revealing a dark abyss of questionable fashion choices. A faint hum of traffic drifts in from the open window, mingling with the distant bark of a neighbor’s dog. The carpet beneath your feet is plush but worn, a testament to years of pacing during late-night phone calls and existential crises. To the east, a door leads to the hallway, while a window to the north offers a view of the backyard—currently just a sea of dew-covered grass and a trampoline that hasn’t been used since 2003.

A nightstand clutters the left side, its surface a graveyard of empty water glasses, a dog-eared paperback, and a lamp that’s seen better days. Across the room, a dresser stands guard over a pile of laundry—clean, but definitely not folded. The closet door hangs slightly ajar, revealing a dark abyss of questionable fashion choices. A faint hum of traffic drifts in from the open window, mingling with the distant bark of a neighbor’s dog. The carpet beneath your feet is plush but worn, a testament to years of pacing during late-night phone calls and existential crises. To the east, a door leads to the hallway, while a window to the north offers a view of the backyard—currently just a sea of dew-covered grass and a trampoline that hasn’t been used since 2003.

room_2886c631.name: The Hallway
room_2886c631.description:
The hallway stretches before you like a time capsule of your own mediocrity. The walls, painted a forgettable shade of beige, are lined with framed photos—most of them blurry, some of them featuring exes you’d rather not remember, and one particularly unflattering shot of you at last year’s office holiday party, mid-sneeze. The carpet here is thinner than in your bedroom, worn down by years of bare feet padding to the bathroom at 3 AM. A faint scent of lavender air freshener lingers, though it’s fighting a losing battle against the underlying odor of old takeout and something vaguely musty. To the south, a door stands slightly ajar, revealing a sliver of the bathroom—where the real chaos begins. To the west, the hallway opens into what you *think* is the living room, though it’s hard to tell from here. A narrow console table hugs the wall beneath a flickering fluorescent light, its surface cluttered with unopened mail, a half-dead potted plant, and a landline phone that hasn’t rung in months.

You can see here: pile of unopened mail, half-dead potted plant, landline phone.

You can see here: pile of unopened mail, half-dead potted plant, landline phone.

room_41056aac.name: The Bathroom
room_41056aac.description:
The bathroom greets you with the kind of humidity that clings to your skin like a bad decision. The mirror above the sink is fogged at the edges, its silver backing peeling in one corner—a relic from the '90s, like most of the decor in this house. The light is harsh, unflattering, the kind that exposes every pore and dark circle you’ve earned from another night of scrolling through late-night infomercials. The shower curtain, a faded floral print, sways slightly, as if someone—or something—just brushed past it. The air smells of damp towels, expired vanilla body wash, and the faintest hint of mildew creeping in from the grout. The sink is a graveyard of half-empty toiletries: a bottle of foundation with a cracked cap, a tube of toothpaste squeezed from the middle, and a razor that’s seen better days. To the north, the hallway beckons, slightly less oppressive than this fluorescent hellscape. The door to the east is now closed, its secrets temporarily locked away. The room feels almost normal again, if you ignore the way the shower curtain still seems to move on its own.

You can see here: foggy mirror, damp towel, expired body wash, old razor.

You can see here: foggy mirror, damp towel, expired body wash.

unmade_bed.name: unmade bed
unmade_bed.description: A queen-sized disaster zone of tangled sheets, a lumpy pillow, and a comforter that’s seen better days. The mattress sags slightly in the middle, a silent testament to years of restless sleep. A single sock clings to the edge, as if it’s too exhausted to fall to the floor. You could make it, but why bother? It’ll just get unmade again tonight.

nightstand.name: nightstand
nightstand.description: A wooden nightstand, its surface scarred by rings from forgotten drinks and the occasional hot coffee mug. The top drawer is slightly open, revealing a tangle of charging cables, a half-empty bottle of hand lotion, and a single, sad AA battery. On top, a stack of unread magazines teeters precariously next to a lamp with a shade that’s slightly askew. A framed photo of you and your college friends—circa 2001—gathers dust next to a glass of water that’s been there so long it’s probably a science experiment now.

laundry_pile.name: pile of laundry
laundry_pile.description: A mountain of clean-but-unfolded clothes, rising like a textile Everest from the floor. Most of it is work-appropriate, but there’s a suspicious amount of yoga pants and oversized sweatshirts mixed in. A lone sock peeks out from the top, daring you to find its mate. The pile smells faintly of fabric softener and regret.

closet_door.name: closet door
closet_door.description: A bi-fold closet door, slightly ajar, revealing a dark and mysterious interior. The door itself is a relic of the 90s, with a faux wood finish that’s seen better days. A single shoelace dangles from the handle, as if someone—or something—tried to escape but gave up halfway. The closet beckons, but you’re not sure you’re ready to face what’s inside.

alarm_clock.name: alarm clock
alarm_clock.description: A digital alarm clock, its red numbers glowing 6:18 AM with the urgency of a countdown to doom. The plastic casing is yellowed with age, and the snooze button is worn smooth from overuse. The alarm is currently silenced, but the memory of its shrill cry still echoes in your skull. A thin layer of dust coats the top, interrupted only by a single fingerprint—yours, from when you smacked it into submission a few minutes ago.

window.name: window
window.description: A large window, its blinds half-open, offering a view of the backyard. The glass is slightly fogged from the morning chill, and a thin layer of pollen dusts the sill. Outside, the world is still waking up: birds chirp lazily, a squirrel darts across the lawn, and the neighbor’s dog barks at nothing in particular. The window is locked, but the latch looks like it hasn’t been tested in years.

pajamas.name: pajamas
pajamas.description: A set of well-worn flannel pajamas, their once-vibrant plaid pattern now faded to a muted blur. The pants are slightly too long, pooling around your ankles, and the shirt has a small coffee stain near the hem—courtesy of last night’s late-night snack. They’re comfortable, but not exactly office-appropriate. The fabric smells faintly of lavender detergent and the faintest hint of desperation.

phone.name: cell phone
phone.description: A flip phone, its silver exterior scratched from years of being tossed into purses and dropped onto nightstands. The screen displays a single notification: "1 New Voicemail." The battery icon is at 42%, which is either a blessing or a curse—you haven’t decided yet. The phone is silent, but you can feel its judgmental gaze, as if it’s disappointed you haven’t upgraded to a smartphone yet.

unopened_mail_pile.name: pile of unopened mail
unopened_mail_pile.description: A leaning tower of envelopes, catalogs, and what might be a jury duty summons buried somewhere near the bottom. The topmost envelope is stamped with the words 'FINAL NOTICE' in bold red letters, but you’ve been ignoring that one for at least a week. The paper feels thin and insubstantial, like it might dissolve if you breathe on it too hard.

dying_potted_plant.name: half-dead potted plant
dying_potted_plant.description: A sad, skeletal thing that was probably a fern at some point. Now, it’s mostly brown twigs and a single, defiant green leaf clinging to life. The soil is cracked and dry, and the pot itself is chipped on one side. You don’t remember buying it, but it’s been here long enough to feel like an indictment of your ability to keep anything alive.

landline_phone.name: landline phone
landline_phone.description: A relic of the 20th century, this corded phone is the color of dishwater and just as appealing. The receiver is slightly sticky, and the cord is tangled into a knot that would make a sailor weep. The voicemail light blinks red, but you’ve long since given up on checking it. Who even calls landlines anymore?

foggy_mirror.name: foggy mirror
foggy_mirror.description: The mirror is a cruel mistress. It’s fogged enough to obscure the worst of your reflection, but not enough to hide the fact that you look like you’ve been dragged backward through a hedge. The silver backing is peeling in one corner, revealing the cheap particleboard beneath. A smudge of last night’s mascara lingers near the bottom, like a dark omen. You could probably wipe it clean, but do you really want to see what’s underneath?

damp_towel.name: damp towel
damp_towel.description: This towel is damp in that specific way that suggests it’s been hanging here for days, slowly fermenting. It’s a faded shade of blue, the edges frayed from too many washes. It smells like a mix of fabric softener and regret. You could use it to dry off, but the thought of pressing it to your face makes your skin crawl.

expired_body_wash.name: expired body wash
expired_body_wash.description: The label on this bottle of body wash is peeling, the expiration date long since faded into obscurity. The liquid inside is a murky, off-white color, and the vanilla scent has soured into something vaguely chemical. It’s the kind of thing you’d throw out if you weren’t too lazy to replace it. The cap is cracked, and a thin film of dried soap crusts the opening.

old_razor.name: old razor
old_razor.description: This razor has seen better days. The plastic handle is yellowed with age, and the blades are dull enough to make shaving feel like a form of self-flagellation. A few rust spots dot the metal, and the grip is slick with old soap scum. You’re pretty sure you’ve been using this same razor since college. It’s a miracle you haven’t given yourself a staph infection yet.
